Simulation-Based Approximate Dynamic Programming

The projection methods from the previous chapter showed how to transform the infinite-dimensional fixed-point problem Lv=v\Bellman v = vLv=v into a finite-dimensional one by choosing basis functions {φi}\{\varphi_i\}{φi​} and imposing conditions that make the residual R(s)=Lv(s)−v(s)R(s) = \Bellman v(s) - v(s)R(s)=Lv(s)−v(s) small. Different projection conditions (Galerkin orthogonality, collocation at points, least squares minimization) yield different finite-dimensional systems to solve.

However, we left unresolved the question of how to evaluate the Bellman operator itself. Applying L\BellmanL at any state requires computing an expectation:

(Lv)(s)=max⁡a∈As{r(s,a)+γ∫v(s′)p(ds′∣s,a)}(\Bellman v)(s) = \max_{a \in \mathcal{A}_s} \left\{r(s,a) + \gamma \int v(s')p(ds'|s,a)\right\}(Lv)(s)=a∈As​max​{r(s,a)+γ∫v(s′)p(ds′∣s,a)}
(1)

For discrete state spaces with a manageable number of states, this expectation is a finite sum we can compute exactly. For continuous or high-dimensional state spaces, we need numerical integration. The projection methods framework is compatible with any quadrature scheme, but leaves the choice of integration method unspecified.

This chapter addresses the integration subproblem that arises at two levels in approximate dynamic programming. First, we must evaluate the transition expectation ∫v(s′)p(ds′∣s,a)\int v(s')p(ds'|s,a)∫v(s′)p(ds′∣s,a) within the Bellman operator itself. Second, when using projection methods like Galerkin or least squares, we encounter outer integrations for enforcing orthogonality conditions or minimizing residuals over distributions of states. Both require numerical approximation in continuous or high-dimensional spaces.

We begin by examining deterministic numerical integration methods: quadrature rules that approximate integrals by evaluating integrands at carefully chosen points with associated weights. We discuss how to coordinate the choice of quadrature with the choice of basis functions to balance approximation accuracy and computational cost. Then we turn to Monte Carlo integration, which approximates expectations using random samples rather than deterministic quadrature points. This shift from deterministic to stochastic integration is what brings us into machine learning territory. When we replace exact transition probabilities with samples drawn from simulations or real interactions, projection methods combined with Monte Carlo integration become what the operations research community calls simulation-based approximate dynamic programming and what the machine learning community calls reinforcement learning. By relying on samples rather than explicit probability functions, we move from model-based planning to data-driven learning.

Evaluating the Bellman Operator with Numerical Quadrature¶

Before turning to Monte Carlo methods, we examine the structure of the numerical integration problem. When we apply the Bellman operator to an approximate value function v^(s;θ)=∑iθiφi(s)\hat{v}(s; \theta) = \sum_i \theta_i \varphi_i(s)v^(s;θ)=∑i​θi​φi​(s), we must evaluate integrals of the form:

∫v^(s′;θ) p(s′∣s,a) ds′=∫(∑iθiφi(s′))p(s′∣s,a) ds′=∑iθi∫φi(s′) p(s′∣s,a) ds′\int \hat{v}(s'; \theta) \, p(s'|s,a) \, ds' = \int \left(\sum_i \theta_i \varphi_i(s')\right) p(s'|s,a) \, ds' = \sum_i \theta_i \int \varphi_i(s') \, p(s'|s,a) \, ds'∫v^(s′;θ)p(s′∣s,a)ds′=∫(i∑​θi​φi​(s′))p(s′∣s,a)ds′=i∑​θi​∫φi​(s′)p(s′∣s,a)ds′
(2)

This shows two independent approximations:

  1. Value function approximation: We represent vvv using basis functions {φi}\{\varphi_i\}{φi​} and coefficients θ\thetaθ

  2. Quadrature approximation: We approximate each integral ∫φi(s′)p(s′∣s,a)ds′\int \varphi_i(s') p(s'|s,a) ds'∫φi​(s′)p(s′∣s,a)ds′ numerically

These choices are independent but should be coordinated. To see why, consider what happens in projection methods when we iterate v^(k+1)=PLv^(k)\hat{v}^{(k+1)} = \Proj \Bellman \hat{v}^{(k)}v^(k+1)=PLv^(k). In practice, we cannot evaluate L\BellmanL exactly due to the integrals, so we compute v^(k+1)=PL~v^(k)\hat{v}^{(k+1)} = \Proj \BellmanQuad \hat{v}^{(k)}v^(k+1)=PLv^(k) instead, where L~\BellmanQuadL denotes the Bellman operator with numerical quadrature.

The error in a single iteration can be bounded by the triangle inequality. Let vvv denote the true fixed point v=Lvv = \Bellman vv=Lv. Then:

∥v−v^(k+1)∥=∥v−PL~v^(k)∥≤∥v−PLv∥+∥PLv−PLv^(k)∥+∥PLv^(k)−PL~v^(k)∥=∥v−PLv∥⏟best approximation error+∥PLv−PLv^(k)∥⏟contraction of iterate error+∥PLv^(k)−PL~v^(k)∥⏟quadrature error\begin{aligned} \|v - \hat{v}^{(k+1)}\| &= \|v - \Proj \BellmanQuad \hat{v}^{(k)}\| \\ &\le \|v - \Proj \Bellman v\| + \|\Proj \Bellman v - \Proj \Bellman \hat{v}^{(k)}\| + \|\Proj \Bellman \hat{v}^{(k)} - \Proj \BellmanQuad \hat{v}^{(k)}\| \\ &= \underbrace{\|v - \Proj \Bellman v\|}_{\text{best approximation error}} + \underbrace{\|\Proj \Bellman v - \Proj \Bellman \hat{v}^{(k)}\|}_{\text{contraction of iterate error}} + \underbrace{\|\Proj \Bellman \hat{v}^{(k)} - \Proj \BellmanQuad \hat{v}^{(k)}\|}_{\text{quadrature error}} \end{aligned}∥v−v^(k+1)∥​=∥v−PLv^(k)∥≤∥v−PLv∥+∥PLv−PLv^(k)∥+∥PLv^(k)−PLv^(k)∥=best approximation error∥v−PLv∥​​+contraction of iterate error∥PLv−PLv^(k)∥​​+quadrature error∥PLv^(k)−PLv^(k)∥​​​
(3)

The first term is the best we can do with our basis (how well P\ProjP approximates the true solution). The second term decreases with iterations when PL\Proj \BellmanPL is a contraction. The third term is the error from replacing exact integrals with quadrature, and it does not vanish as iterations proceed.

To make this concrete, consider evaluating (Lv^)(s)(\Bellman \hat{v})(s)(Lv^)(s) for our current approximation v^(s;θ)=∑iθiφi(s)\hat{v}(s; \theta) = \sum_i \theta_i \varphi_i(s)v^(s;θ)=∑i​θi​φi​(s). We want:

(Lv^)(s)=max⁡a∈As{r(s,a)+γ∑iθi∫φi(s′)p(s′∣s,a)ds′}(\Bellman \hat{v})(s) = \max_{a \in \mathcal{A}_s} \left\{r(s,a) + \gamma \sum_i \theta_i \int \varphi_i(s') p(s'|s,a) ds' \right\}(Lv^)(s)=a∈As​max​{r(s,a)+γi∑​θi​∫φi​(s′)p(s′∣s,a)ds′}
(4)

But we compute instead:

(L~v^)(s)=max⁡a∈As{r(s,a)+γ∑iθi∑jwjφi(sj′)}(\BellmanQuad \hat{v})(s) = \max_{a \in \mathcal{A}_s} \left\{r(s,a) + \gamma \sum_i \theta_i \sum_j w_j \varphi_i(s'_j) \right\}(Lv^)(s)=a∈As​max​{r(s,a)+γi∑​θi​j∑​wj​φi​(sj′​)}
(5)

where {(sj′,wj)}\{(s'_j, w_j)\}{(sj′​,wj​)} are quadrature nodes and weights. If the quadrature error ∥(Lv^)(s)−(L~v^)(s)∥\|(\Bellman \hat{v})(s) - (\BellmanQuad \hat{v})(s)\|∥(Lv^)(s)−(Lv^)(s)∥ is large relative to the basis approximation quality, we cannot exploit the expressive power of the basis. For instance, degree-10 Chebyshev polynomials represent smooth functions to O(10−8)O(10^{-8})O(10−8) accuracy, but combined with rectangle-rule quadrature (error O(h2)≈10−2O(h^2) \approx 10^{-2}O(h2)≈10−2), the quadrature term dominates the error bound. We pay the cost of storing and manipulating 10 coefficients but achieve only O(h2)O(h^2)O(h2) convergence in the quadrature mesh size.

This echoes the coordination principle from continuous optimal control (Chapter on trajectory optimization): when transcribing a continuous-time problem, we use the same quadrature nodes for both the running cost integral and the dynamics integral. There, coordination ensures that “where we pay” aligns with “where we enforce” the dynamics. Here, coordination ensures that integration accuracy matches approximation accuracy. Both are instances of balancing multiple sources of error in numerical methods.

Standard basis-quadrature pairings achieve this balance:

  • Piecewise constant or linear elements with midpoint or trapezoidal rules

  • Chebyshev polynomials with Gauss-Chebyshev quadrature

  • Legendre polynomials with Gauss-Legendre quadrature

  • Hermite polynomials with Gauss-Hermite quadrature (for Gaussian shocks)

To make this concrete, we examine what these pairings look like in practice for collocation and Galerkin projection.

Orthogonal Collocation with Chebyshev Polynomials¶

Consider approximating the value function using Chebyshev polynomials of degree n−1n-1n−1:

v^(s;θ)=∑i=0n−1θiTi(s)\hat{v}(s; \theta) = \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} \theta_i T_i(s)v^(s;θ)=i=0∑n−1​θi​Ti​(s)
(6)

For orthogonal collocation, we place collocation points at the zeros of Tn(s)T_n(s)Tn​(s), denoted {sj}j=1n\{s_j\}_{j=1}^n{sj​}j=1n​. At each collocation point, we require the Bellman equation to hold exactly:

v^(sj;θ)=max⁡a∈A{r(sj,a)+γ∫v^(s′;θ)p(ds′∣sj,a)}\hat{v}(s_j; \theta) = \max_{a \in \mathcal{A}} \left\{r(s_j,a) + \gamma \int \hat{v}(s'; \theta) p(ds'|s_j,a)\right\}v^(sj​;θ)=a∈Amax​{r(sj​,a)+γ∫v^(s′;θ)p(ds′∣sj​,a)}
(7)

The integral on the right must be approximated using quadrature. With Chebyshev-Gauss quadrature using the same nodes {sk}k=1n\{s_k\}_{k=1}^n{sk​}k=1n​ and weights {wk}k=1n\{w_k\}_{k=1}^n{wk​}k=1n​, this becomes:

v^(sj;θ)=max⁡a∈A{r(sj,a)+γ∑k=1nwkv^(sk;θ)p(sk∣sj,a)}\hat{v}(s_j; \theta) = \max_{a \in \mathcal{A}} \left\{r(s_j,a) + \gamma \sum_{k=1}^n w_k \hat{v}(s_k; \theta) p(s_k|s_j,a)\right\}v^(sj​;θ)=a∈Amax​{r(sj​,a)+γk=1∑n​wk​v^(sk​;θ)p(sk​∣sj​,a)}
(8)

Substituting the basis representation v^(sk;θ)=∑i=0n−1θiTi(sk)\hat{v}(s_k; \theta) = \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} \theta_i T_i(s_k)v^(sk​;θ)=∑i=0n−1​θi​Ti​(sk​):

∑i=0n−1θiTi(sj)=max⁡a∈A{r(sj,a)+γ∑k=1nwkp(sk∣sj,a)∑i=0n−1θiTi(sk)}\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} \theta_i T_i(s_j) = \max_{a \in \mathcal{A}} \left\{r(s_j,a) + \gamma \sum_{k=1}^n w_k p(s_k|s_j,a) \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} \theta_i T_i(s_k)\right\}i=0∑n−1​θi​Ti​(sj​)=a∈Amax​{r(sj​,a)+γk=1∑n​wk​p(sk​∣sj​,a)i=0∑n−1​θi​Ti​(sk​)}
(9)

Rearranging:

∑i=0n−1θiTi(sj)=max⁡a∈A{r(sj,a)+γ∑i=0n−1θi∑k=1nwkTi(sk)p(sk∣sj,a)⏟Bjia}\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} \theta_i T_i(s_j) = \max_{a \in \mathcal{A}} \left\{r(s_j,a) + \gamma \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} \theta_i \underbrace{\sum_{k=1}^n w_k T_i(s_k) p(s_k|s_j,a)}_{B_{ji}^a}\right\}i=0∑n−1​θi​Ti​(sj​)=a∈Amax​⎩⎨⎧​r(sj​,a)+γi=0∑n−1​θi​Bjia​k=1∑n​wk​Ti​(sk​)p(sk​∣sj​,a)​​⎭⎬⎫​
(10)

This yields a system of nnn nonlinear equations (one per collocation point):

∑i=0n−1Ti(sj)θi=max⁡a∈A{r(sj,a)+γ∑i=0n−1Bjiaθi},j=1,…,n\sum_{i=0}^{n-1} T_i(s_j) \theta_i = \max_{a \in \mathcal{A}} \left\{r(s_j,a) + \gamma \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} B_{ji}^a \theta_i\right\}, \quad j=1,\ldots,ni=0∑n−1​Ti​(sj​)θi​=a∈Amax​{r(sj​,a)+γi=0∑n−1​Bjia​θi​},j=1,…,n
(11)

The matrix elements BjiaB_{ji}^aBjia​ can be precomputed once the quadrature nodes, weights, and transition probabilities are known. Solving this system gives the coefficient vector θ\thetaθ.

Galerkin Projection with Hermite Polynomials¶

For a problem with Gaussian shocks, we might use Hermite polynomials {Hi(s)}i=0n−1\{H_i(s)\}_{i=0}^{n-1}{Hi​(s)}i=0n−1​ weighted by the Gaussian density ϕ(s)\phi(s)ϕ(s). The Galerkin condition requires:

∫(Lv^(s;θ)−v^(s;θ))Hj(s)ϕ(s)ds=0,j=0,…,n−1\int \left(\Bellman \hat{v}(s; \theta) - \hat{v}(s; \theta)\right) H_j(s) \phi(s) ds = 0, \quad j=0,\ldots,n-1∫(Lv^(s;θ)−v^(s;θ))Hj​(s)ϕ(s)ds=0,j=0,…,n−1
(12)

Expanding the Bellman operator:

∫[max⁡a∈A{r(s,a)+γ∫v^(s′;θ)p(ds′∣s,a)}−v^(s;θ)]Hj(s)ϕ(s)ds=0\int \left[\max_{a \in \mathcal{A}} \left\{r(s,a) + \gamma \int \hat{v}(s'; \theta) p(ds'|s,a)\right\} - \hat{v}(s; \theta)\right] H_j(s) \phi(s) ds = 0∫[a∈Amax​{r(s,a)+γ∫v^(s′;θ)p(ds′∣s,a)}−v^(s;θ)]Hj​(s)ϕ(s)ds=0
(13)

We approximate this outer integral using Gauss-Hermite quadrature with nodes {sℓ}ℓ=1m\{s_\ell\}_{\ell=1}^m{sℓ​}ℓ=1m​ and weights {wℓ}ℓ=1m\{w_\ell\}_{\ell=1}^m{wℓ​}ℓ=1m​:

∑ℓ=1mwℓ[max⁡a∈A{r(sℓ,a)+γ∫v^(s′;θ)p(ds′∣sℓ,a)}−v^(sℓ;θ)]Hj(sℓ)=0\sum_{\ell=1}^m w_\ell \left[\max_{a \in \mathcal{A}} \left\{r(s_\ell,a) + \gamma \int \hat{v}(s'; \theta) p(ds'|s_\ell,a)\right\} - \hat{v}(s_\ell; \theta)\right] H_j(s_\ell) = 0ℓ=1∑m​wℓ​[a∈Amax​{r(sℓ​,a)+γ∫v^(s′;θ)p(ds′∣sℓ​,a)}−v^(sℓ​;θ)]Hj​(sℓ​)=0
(14)

The inner integral (transition expectation) is also approximated using Gauss-Hermite quadrature:

∫v^(s′;θ)p(ds′∣sℓ,a)≈∑k=1mwkv^(sk;θ)p(sk∣sℓ,a)\int \hat{v}(s'; \theta) p(ds'|s_\ell,a) \approx \sum_{k=1}^m w_k \hat{v}(s_k; \theta) p(s_k|s_\ell,a)∫v^(s′;θ)p(ds′∣sℓ​,a)≈k=1∑m​wk​v^(sk​;θ)p(sk​∣sℓ​,a)
(15)

Substituting the basis representation and collecting terms:

∑ℓ=1mwℓHj(sℓ)max⁡a∈A{r(sℓ,a)+γ∑i=0n−1θi∑k=1mwkHi(sk)p(sk∣sℓ,a)}=∑ℓ=1mwℓHj(sℓ)∑i=0n−1θiHi(sℓ)\sum_{\ell=1}^m w_\ell H_j(s_\ell) \max_{a \in \mathcal{A}} \left\{r(s_\ell,a) + \gamma \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} \theta_i \sum_{k=1}^m w_k H_i(s_k) p(s_k|s_\ell,a)\right\} = \sum_{\ell=1}^m w_\ell H_j(s_\ell) \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} \theta_i H_i(s_\ell)ℓ=1∑m​wℓ​Hj​(sℓ​)a∈Amax​{r(sℓ​,a)+γi=0∑n−1​θi​k=1∑m​wk​Hi​(sk​)p(sk​∣sℓ​,a)}=ℓ=1∑m​wℓ​Hj​(sℓ​)i=0∑n−1​θi​Hi​(sℓ​)
(16)

This gives nnn nonlinear equations in nnn unknowns. The right-hand side simplifies using orthogonality: when using the same quadrature nodes for projection and integration, ∑ℓ=1mwℓHj(sℓ)Hi(sℓ)=δij∥Hj∥2\sum_{\ell=1}^m w_\ell H_j(s_\ell) H_i(s_\ell) = \delta_{ij} \|H_j\|^2∑ℓ=1m​wℓ​Hj​(sℓ​)Hi​(sℓ​)=δij​∥Hj​∥2.

In both cases, the basis-quadrature pairing ensures that:

  1. The quadrature nodes appear in both the transition expectation and the outer projection

  2. The quadrature accuracy matches the polynomial approximation order

  3. Precomputed matrices capture the dynamics, making iterations efficient

Monte Carlo Integration¶

Deterministic quadrature rules work well when the state space has low dimension, the transition density is smooth, and we can evaluate it cheaply at arbitrary points. In many stochastic control problems none of these conditions truly hold. The state may be high dimensional, the dynamics may be given by a simulator rather than an explicit density, and the cost of each call to the model may be large. In that regime, deterministic quadrature becomes brittle. Monte Carlo methods offer a different way to approximate expectations, one that relies only on the ability to sample from the relevant distributions.

Monte Carlo as randomized quadrature¶

Consider a single expectation of the form

J=∫f(x) p(dx)=E[f(X)],J = \int f(x)\,p(dx) = \mathbb{E}[f(X)],J=∫f(x)p(dx)=E[f(X)],
(17)

where X∼pX \sim pX∼p and fff is some integrable function. Monte Carlo integration approximates JJJ by drawing independent samples X(1),…,X(N)∼pX^{(1)},\ldots,X^{(N)} \sim pX(1),…,X(N)∼p and forming the sample average

J^N≡1N∑n=1Nf(X(n)).\hat{J}_N \equiv \frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^N f\bigl(X^{(n)}\bigr).J^N​≡N1​n=1∑N​f(X(n)).
(18)

This estimator has two basic properties that will matter throughout this chapter.

First, it is unbiased:

E[J^N]=E[1N∑n=1Nf(X(n))]=1N∑n=1NE[f(X(n))]=E[f(X)]=J.\mathbb{E}[\hat{J}_N] = \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^N f(X^{(n)})\right] = \frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^N \mathbb{E}[f(X^{(n)})] = \mathbb{E}[f(X)] = J.E[J^N​]=E[N1​n=1∑N​f(X(n))]=N1​n=1∑N​E[f(X(n))]=E[f(X)]=J.
(19)

Second, its variance scales as 1/N1/N1/N. If we write

σ2≡Var[f(X)],\sigma^2 \equiv \mathrm{Var}[f(X)],σ2≡Var[f(X)],
(20)

then independence of the samples gives

Var(J^N)=1N2∑n=1NVar(f(X(n)))=σ2N.\mathrm{Var}(\hat{J}_N) = \frac{1}{N^2}\sum_{n=1}^N \mathrm{Var}\bigl(f(X^{(n)})\bigr) = \frac{\sigma^2}{N}.Var(J^N​)=N21​n=1∑N​Var(f(X(n)))=Nσ2​.
(21)

The central limit theorem then says that for large NNN,

N (J^N−J)⟹N(0,σ2),\sqrt{N}\,(\hat{J}_N - J) \Longrightarrow \mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^2),N​(J^N​−J)⟹N(0,σ2),
(22)

so the integration error decays at rate O(N−1/2)O(N^{-1/2})O(N−1/2). This rate is slow compared to high-order quadrature in low dimension, but it has one crucial advantage: it does not explicitly depend on the dimension of xxx. Monte Carlo integration pays in variance, not in an exponential growth in the number of nodes.

It is often helpful to view Monte Carlo as randomized quadrature. A deterministic quadrature rule selects nodes xjx_jxj​ and weights wjw_jwj​ in advance and computes

∑jwjf(xj).\sum_j w_j f(x_j).j∑​wj​f(xj​).
(23)

Monte Carlo can be written in the same form: if we draw X(n)X^{(n)}X(n) from density ppp, the sample average

J^N=1N∑n=1Nf(X(n))\hat{J}_N = \frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^N f(X^{(n)})J^N​=N1​n=1∑N​f(X(n))
(24)

is just a quadrature rule with random nodes and equal weights. More advanced Monte Carlo schemes, such as importance sampling, change both the sampling distribution and the weights, but the basic idea remains the same.

Monte Carlo evaluation of the Bellman operator¶

We now apply this to the Bellman operator. For a fixed value function vvv and a given state-action pair (s,a)(s,a)(s,a), the transition part of the Bellman operator is

∫v(s′) p(ds′∣s,a)=E[v(S′)∣S=s,A=a].\int v(s')\,p(ds' \mid s,a) = \mathbb{E}\left[v(S') \mid S = s, A = a\right].∫v(s′)p(ds′∣s,a)=E[v(S′)∣S=s,A=a].
(25)

If we can simulate next states S′(1),…,S′(N)S'^{(1)},\ldots,S'^{(N)}S′(1),…,S′(N) from the transition kernel p(⋅∣s,a)p(\cdot \mid s,a)p(⋅∣s,a), either by calling a simulator or by interacting with the environment, we can approximate this expectation by

E^N[v(S′)∣s,a]≡1N∑n=1Nv(S′(n)).\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_N\bigl[v(S') \mid s,a\bigr] \equiv \frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^N v\bigl(S'^{(n)}\bigr).EN​[v(S′)∣s,a]≡N1​n=1∑N​v(S′(n)).
(26)

If the immediate reward is also random, say

r=r(S,A,S′)with(S′,r)∼p(⋅∣s,a),r = r(S,A,S') \quad \text{with} \quad (S', r) \sim p(\cdot \mid s,a),r=r(S,A,S′)with(S′,r)∼p(⋅∣s,a),
(27)

we can approximate the full one-step return

E[r+γv(S′)∣S=s,A=a]\mathbb{E}\bigl[r + \gamma v(S') \mid S = s, A = a\bigr]E[r+γv(S′)∣S=s,A=a]
(28)

by

G^N(s,a)≡1N∑n=1N[r(n)+γv(S′(n))],\widehat{G}_N(s,a) \equiv \frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^N \bigl[r^{(n)} + \gamma v(S'^{(n)})\bigr],GN​(s,a)≡N1​n=1∑N​[r(n)+γv(S′(n))],
(29)

where (r(n),S′(n))(r^{(n)}, S'^{(n)})(r(n),S′(n)) are independent samples given (s,a)(s,a)(s,a). Again, this is an unbiased estimator of the Bellman expectation for fixed vvv.

Plugging this into the Bellman operator gives a Monte Carlo Bellman operator:

(L^Nv)(s)≡max⁡a∈As{G^N(s,a)}.(\widehat{\Bellman}_N v)(s) \equiv \max_{a \in \mathcal{A}_s} \left\{ \widehat{G}_N(s,a) \right\}.(LN​v)(s)≡a∈As​max​{GN​(s,a)}.
(30)

The expectation inside the braces is now replaced by a random sample average. In model-based settings, we implement this by simulating many next states for each candidate action aaa at state sss. In model-free settings, we obtain samples from real interactions and re-use them to estimate the expectation.

At this stage nothing about approximation or projection has entered yet. For a fixed value function vvv, Monte Carlo provides unbiased, noisy evaluations of (Lv)(s)(\Bellman v)(s)(Lv)(s). The approximation question arises once we couple this stochastic evaluation with basis functions and projections.

Sampling the outer expectations¶

Projection methods introduce a second layer of integration. In Galerkin and least squares schemes, we choose a distribution μ\muμ over states (and sometimes actions) and enforce conditions of the form

∫R(s;θ) pi(s) μ(ds)=0or∫R(s;θ)2 μ(ds) is minimized.\int R(s; \theta)\,p_i(s)\, \mu(ds) = 0 \quad \text{or} \quad \int R(s; \theta)^2\,\mu(ds) \text{ is minimized}.∫R(s;θ)pi​(s)μ(ds)=0or∫R(s;θ)2μ(ds) is minimized.
(31)

Here R(s;θ)R(s; \theta)R(s;θ) is the residual function, such as

R(s;θ)=(Lv^)(s;θ)−v^(s;θ),R(s; \theta) = (\Bellman \hat{v})(s;\theta) - \hat{v}(s;\theta),R(s;θ)=(Lv^)(s;θ)−v^(s;θ),
(32)

and pip_ipi​ are test functions or derivatives of the residual with respect to parameters.

Note a subtle but important shift in perspective from the previous chapter. There, the weight function w(s)w(s)w(s) in the inner product ⟨f,g⟩w=∫f(s)g(s)w(s)ds\langle f, g \rangle_w = \int f(s) g(s) w(s) ds⟨f,g⟩w​=∫f(s)g(s)w(s)ds could be any positive weight function (not necessarily normalized). For Monte Carlo integration, however, we need a probability distribution we can sample from. We write μ\muμ for this sampling distribution and express projection conditions as integrals with respect to μ\muμ: ∫R(s;θ)pi(s)μ(ds)\int R(s; \theta) p_i(s) \mu(ds)∫R(s;θ)pi​(s)μ(ds). If a problem was originally formulated with an unnormalized weight w(s)w(s)w(s), we must either (i) normalize it to define μ\muμ, or (ii) use importance sampling with a different μ\muμ and reweight samples by w(s)/μ(s)w(s)/\mu(s)w(s)/μ(s). In reinforcement learning, μ\muμ is typically the empirical state visitation distribution from collected trajectories.

These outer integrals over sss are generally not easier to compute than the inner transition expectations. Monte Carlo gives a way to approximate them as well. If we can draw states S(1),…,S(M)∼μS^{(1)},\ldots,S^{(M)} \sim \muS(1),…,S(M)∼μ, we can approximate, for example, the Galerkin orthogonality conditions by

∫R(s;θ) pi(s) μ(ds)≈1M∑m=1MR(S(m);θ) pi(S(m)).\int R(s; \theta)\,p_i(s)\,\mu(ds) \approx \frac{1}{M}\sum_{m=1}^M R\bigl(S^{(m)}; \theta\bigr)\,p_i\bigl(S^{(m)}\bigr).∫R(s;θ)pi​(s)μ(ds)≈M1​m=1∑M​R(S(m);θ)pi​(S(m)).
(33)

Similarly, a least squares objective

∫R(s;θ)2 μ(ds)\int R(s; \theta)^2\,\mu(ds)∫R(s;θ)2μ(ds)
(34)

is approximated by the empirical risk

1M∑m=1MR(S(m);θ)2.\frac{1}{M}\sum_{m=1}^M R\bigl(S^{(m)}; \theta\bigr)^2.M1​m=1∑M​R(S(m);θ)2.
(35)

If we now substitute Monte Carlo estimates for both the inner transition expectations and the outer projection conditions, we obtain fully simulation-based schemes. We no longer need explicit access to the transition kernel p(⋅∣s,a)p(\cdot \mid s,a)p(⋅∣s,a) or the state distribution μ\muμ. It is enough to be able to sample from them, either through a simulator or by interacting with the real system.

Simulation-Based Projection Methods¶

Monte Carlo integration replaces both levels of integration in approximate dynamic programming. The transition expectation in the Bellman operator becomes 1N∑n=1Nv(S′(n))\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^N v(S'^{(n)})N1​∑n=1N​v(S′(n)), and the outer integrals for projection become empirical averages over sampled states. Writing PM\Proj_MPM​ for projection using MMM state samples and L^N\widehat{\Bellman}_NLN​ for the Monte Carlo Bellman operator with NNN transition samples, the iteration becomes

v^(k+1)=PM L^Nv^(k).\hat{v}^{(k+1)} = \Proj_M\,\widehat{\Bellman}_N \hat{v}^{(k)}.v^(k+1)=PM​LN​v^(k).
(36)

Unlike deterministic quadrature, which introduces a fixed bias at each iteration, Monte Carlo introduces random error with zero mean but nonzero variance. However, combining Monte Carlo with the maximization in the Bellman operator creates a systematic problem: while the estimate of the expected return for any individual action is unbiased, taking the maximum over these noisy estimates introduces upward bias. This overestimation compounds through value iteration and degrades the resulting policies.

Amortizing Action Selection via Q-Functions¶

Monte Carlo integration enables model-free approximate dynamic programming: we no longer need explicit transition probabilities p(s′∣s,a)p(s'|s,a)p(s′∣s,a), only the ability to sample next states. However, one computational challenge remains. The standard formulation of an optimal decision rule is

π(s)=arg⁡max⁡a∈A{r(s,a)+γ∫v(s′)p(ds′∣s,a)}.\pi(s) = \arg\max_{a \in \mathcal{A}} \left\{r(s,a) + \gamma \int v(s')p(ds'|s,a)\right\}.π(s)=arga∈Amax​{r(s,a)+γ∫v(s′)p(ds′∣s,a)}.
(37)

Even with an optimal value function v∗v^*v∗ in hand, extracting an action at state sss requires evaluating the transition expectation for each candidate action. In the model-free setting, this means we must draw Monte Carlo samples from each action’s transition distribution every time we select an action. This repeated sampling “at inference time” wastes computation, especially when the same state is visited multiple times.

We can amortize this computation by working at a different level of representation. Define the state-action value function (or Q-function)

q(s,a)=r(s,a)+γ∫v(s′)p(ds′∣s,a).q(s,a) = r(s,a) + \gamma \int v(s')p(ds'|s,a).q(s,a)=r(s,a)+γ∫v(s′)p(ds′∣s,a).
(38)

The Q-function caches the result of evaluating each action at each state. Once we have qqq, action selection reduces to a finite maximization:

π(s)=arg⁡max⁡a∈A(s)q(s,a).\pi(s) = \arg\max_{a \in \mathcal{A}(s)} q(s,a).π(s)=arga∈A(s)max​q(s,a).
(39)

No integration appears in this expression. The transition expectation has been precomputed and stored in qqq itself.

The optimal Q-function q∗q^*q∗ satisfies its own Bellman equation. Substituting the definition of v∗(s)=max⁡aq∗(s,a)v^*(s) = \max_a q^*(s,a)v∗(s)=maxa​q∗(s,a) into the expression for qqq:

q∗(s,a)=r(s,a)+γ∫p(ds′∣s,a)max⁡a′∈A(s′)q∗(s′,a′).q^*(s,a) = r(s,a) + \gamma \int p(ds'|s,a) \max_{a' \in \mathcal{A}(s')} q^*(s', a').q∗(s,a)=r(s,a)+γ∫p(ds′∣s,a)a′∈A(s′)max​q∗(s′,a′).
(40)

This defines a Bellman operator on Q-functions:

(Lq)(s,a)=r(s,a)+γ∫p(ds′∣s,a)max⁡a′∈A(s′)q(s′,a′).(\Bellman q)(s,a) = r(s,a) + \gamma \int p(ds'|s,a)\max_{a' \in \mathcal{A}(s')} q(s', a').(Lq)(s,a)=r(s,a)+γ∫p(ds′∣s,a)a′∈A(s′)max​q(s′,a′).
(41)

Like the Bellman operator on value functions, L\BellmanL is a γ\gammaγ-contraction in the sup-norm, guaranteeing a unique fixed point q∗q^*q∗. We can thus apply the same projection and Monte Carlo techniques developed for value functions to Q-functions. The computational cost shifts from action selection (repeated sampling at decision time) to training (evaluating expectations during the iterations of approximate value iteration). Once qqq is learned, acting is cheap.

Algorithm 1 (Parametric Q-Value Iteration)

Input Given an MDP (S,A,P,R,γ)(S, A, P, R, \gamma)(S,A,P,R,γ), base points B⊂S\mathcal{B} \subset SB⊂S, function approximator class q(s,a;θ)q(s,a; \boldsymbol{\theta})q(s,a;θ), maximum iterations NNN, tolerance ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0

Output Parameters θ\boldsymbol{\theta}θ for Q-function approximation

  1. Initialize θ0\boldsymbol{\theta}_0θ0​ (e.g., for zero initialization)

  2. n←0n \leftarrow 0n←0

  3. repeat

    1. D←∅\mathcal{D} \leftarrow \emptysetD←∅

    2. For each (s,a)∈B×A(s,a) \in \mathcal{B} \times A(s,a)∈B×A:

      1. ys,a←r(s,a)+γ∫p(ds′∣s,a)max⁡a′∈Aq(s′,a′;θn)y_{s,a} \leftarrow r(s,a) + \gamma \int p(ds'|s,a)\max_{a' \in A} q(s',a'; \boldsymbol{\theta}_n)ys,a​←r(s,a)+γ∫p(ds′∣s,a)maxa′∈A​q(s′,a′;θn​)

      2. D←D∪{((s,a),ys,a)}\mathcal{D} \leftarrow \mathcal{D} \cup \{((s,a), y_{s,a})\}D←D∪{((s,a),ys,a​)}

    3. θn+1←fit(D)\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n+1} \leftarrow \texttt{fit}(\mathcal{D})θn+1​←fit(D)

    4. δ←1∣D∣∣A∣∑(s,a)∈D×A(q(s,a;θn+1)−q(s,a;θn))2\delta \leftarrow \frac{1}{|\mathcal{D}||A|}\sum_{(s,a) \in \mathcal{D} \times A} (q(s,a; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{n+1}) - q(s,a; \boldsymbol{\theta}_n))^2δ←∣D∣∣A∣1​∑(s,a)∈D×A​(q(s,a;θn+1​)−q(s,a;θn​))2

    5. n←n+1n \leftarrow n + 1n←n+1

  4. until (δ<ε\delta < \varepsilonδ<ε or n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N)

  5. return θn\boldsymbol{\theta}_nθn​

Upward Bias from Maximizing Noisy Estimates¶

The source of the problem is simple to state: we are now optimizing over noisy estimates of expected returns. Each Monte Carlo estimate is, by itself, unbiased. The bias appears when we take a maximum over several such noisy estimates and then feed that maximum back into the next iteration.

Fix some state sss and a current value function vvv. For each action aaa, define the true expected continuation value

μ(s,a)≡∫v(s′) p(ds′∣s,a),\mu(s,a) \equiv \int v(s')\,p(ds' \mid s,a),μ(s,a)≡∫v(s′)p(ds′∣s,a),
(42)

so that the exact Bellman update is

(Lv)(s)=max⁡a∈As{r(s,a)+γμ(s,a)}.(\Bellman v)(s) = \max_{a \in \mathcal{A}_s} \left\{ r(s,a) + \gamma \mu(s,a)\right\}.(Lv)(s)=a∈As​max​{r(s,a)+γμ(s,a)}.
(43)

Under Monte Carlo integration with NNN samples, we replace μ(s,a)\mu(s,a)μ(s,a) by the empirical mean

μ^N(s,a)≡1N∑i=1Nv(si′),si′∼p(⋅∣s,a),\hat{\mu}_N(s,a) \equiv \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N v(s'_{i}), \quad s'_{i} \sim p(\cdot \mid s,a),μ^​N​(s,a)≡N1​i=1∑N​v(si′​),si′​∼p(⋅∣s,a),
(44)

and define the empirical Bellman update

(L^Nv)(s)=max⁡a∈As{r(s,a)+γμ^N(s,a)}.(\widehat{\Bellman}_N v)(s) = \max_{a \in \mathcal{A}_s} \left\{ r(s,a) + \gamma \hat{\mu}_N(s,a)\right\}.(LN​v)(s)=a∈As​max​{r(s,a)+γμ^​N​(s,a)}.
(45)

For any fixed sss and aaa, the Monte Carlo estimator is unbiased:

E[μ^N(s,a)]=μ(s,a).\mathbb{E}\big[\hat{\mu}_N(s,a)\big] = \mu(s,a).E[μ^​N​(s,a)]=μ(s,a).
(46)

If we removed the maximization over actions, we would have an unbiased approximation of (Lv)(s)(\Bellman v)(s)(Lv)(s). The problem is that we do not remove it. Instead, we compute

max⁡a{r(s,a)+γμ^N(s,a)},\max_a \left\{ r(s,a) + \gamma \hat{\mu}_N(s,a)\right\},amax​{r(s,a)+γμ^​N​(s,a)},
(47)

where each term inside the maximum is a random quantity. The nonlinearity of the max operator breaks unbiasedness.

A Simple Inequality¶

To see this clearly, suppress sss in the notation and consider random variables

Ya≡r(a)+γμ^N(a),a∈A,Y_a \equiv r(a) + \gamma \hat{\mu}_N(a), \quad a \in \mathcal{A},Ya​≡r(a)+γμ^​N​(a),a∈A,
(48)

with expectations

E[Ya]=r(a)+γμ(a).\mathbb{E}[Y_a] = r(a) + \gamma \mu(a).E[Ya​]=r(a)+γμ(a).
(49)

Let a∗a^*a∗ be any action that maximizes the true expected return:

a∗∈arg⁡max⁡a{r(a)+γμ(a)}.a^* \in \arg\max_{a} \left\{r(a) + \gamma \mu(a)\right\}.a∗∈argamax​{r(a)+γμ(a)}.
(50)

Then, for every outcome of the randomness,

max⁡aYa≥Ya∗.\max_a Y_a \ge Y_{a^*}.amax​Ya​≥Ya∗​.
(51)

This is not a probabilistic statement but a simple algebraic fact: the maximum of a collection of numbers is at least as large as any particular element of that collection. Since this inequality holds for every realization of the random variables, we can take expectations on both sides. Expectation is monotone: if X≥ZX \ge ZX≥Z almost surely, then E[X]≥E[Z]\mathbb{E}[X] \ge \mathbb{E}[Z]E[X]≥E[Z]. Applying this gives

E[max⁡aYa]≥E[Ya∗]=r(a∗)+γμ(a∗)=(Lv)(s).\mathbb{E}\big[\max_a Y_a\big] \ge \mathbb{E}[Y_{a^*}] = r(a^*) + \gamma \mu(a^*) = (\Bellman v)(s).E[amax​Ya​]≥E[Ya∗​]=r(a∗)+γμ(a∗)=(Lv)(s).
(52)

So we obtain the inequality

E[(L^Nv)(s)]=E[max⁡a{r(s,a)+γμ^N(s,a)}]≥(Lv)(s).\mathbb{E}\big[(\widehat{\Bellman}_N v)(s)\big] = \mathbb{E}\Big[\max_a \left\{r(s,a) + \gamma \hat{\mu}_N(s,a)\right\}\Big] \ge (\Bellman v)(s).E[(LN​v)(s)]=E[amax​{r(s,a)+γμ^​N​(s,a)}]≥(Lv)(s).
(53)

The inequality is strict as soon as there is more than one action and at least one of the μ^N(s,a)\hat{\mu}_N(s,a)μ^​N​(s,a) has nonzero variance. In other words, even if each action’s Monte Carlo estimate is unbiased, the maximization step introduces an upward bias.

This is a general phenomenon: for any collection of random variables {Ya}\{Y_a\}{Ya​},

E[max⁡aYa]≥max⁡aE[Ya],\mathbb{E}[\max_a Y_a] \ge \max_a \mathbb{E}[Y_a],E[amax​Ya​]≥amax​E[Ya​],
(54)

because the maximum of random variables is a convex function of the vector (Ya)a(Y_a)_a(Ya​)a​. We have simply applied that fact in the specific setting of our empirical Bellman operator.

A One-State Thought Experiment¶

It is instructive to strip away all structure and consider a one-state MDP with two actions a1a_1a1​ and a2a_2a2​. Suppose that, under the current value function vvv, both actions have the same true continuation value:

μ(a1)=μ(a2)=μ.\mu(a_1) = \mu(a_2) = \mu.μ(a1​)=μ(a2​)=μ.
(55)

We estimate each using

μ^N(ai)=μ+εi,i=1,2,\hat{\mu}_N(a_i) = \mu + \varepsilon_i, \quad i = 1,2,μ^​N​(ai​)=μ+εi​,i=1,2,
(56)

where ε1\varepsilon_1ε1​ and ε2\varepsilon_2ε2​ are zero-mean noise terms (for instance, independent Gaussian random variables with variance σ2/N\sigma^2/Nσ2/N).

Then

(Lv)=r+γμ(\Bellman v) = r + \gamma \mu(Lv)=r+γμ
(57)

is the true next value, while the empirical update is

(L^Nv)=r+γmax⁡{μ^N(a1),μ^N(a2)}=r+γ(μ+max⁡{ε1,ε2}).\begin{aligned} (\widehat{\Bellman}_N v) &= r + \gamma \max\{\hat{\mu}_N(a_1), \hat{\mu}_N(a_2)\} \\ &= r + \gamma \left(\mu + \max\{\varepsilon_1,\varepsilon_2\}\right). \end{aligned}(LN​v)​=r+γmax{μ^​N​(a1​),μ^​N​(a2​)}=r+γ(μ+max{ε1​,ε2​}).​
(58)

Since ε1\varepsilon_1ε1​ and ε2\varepsilon_2ε2​ are symmetric around zero, the expected maximum of the two is strictly positive:

E[max⁡{ε1,ε2}]>0.\mathbb{E}[\max\{\varepsilon_1,\varepsilon_2\}] > 0.E[max{ε1​,ε2​}]>0.
(59)

Consequently,

E[(L^Nv)]=r+γ(μ+E[max⁡{ε1,ε2}])>r+γμ=(Lv).\begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}\big[(\widehat{\Bellman}_N v)\big] &= r + \gamma \left(\mu + \mathbb{E}[\max\{\varepsilon_1,\varepsilon_2\}]\right) \\ &> r + \gamma \mu \\ &= (\Bellman v). \end{aligned}E[(LN​v)]​=r+γ(μ+E[max{ε1​,ε2​}])>r+γμ=(Lv).​
(60)

Nothing in the problem “wants” action a1a_1a1​ or a2a_2a2​ to be better. The only asymmetry comes from the random noise. Yet by always picking the empirically best action, we systematically favor “lucky” noise realizations. The algorithm interprets these lucky draws as evidence that the optimal value is higher than it truly is.

Bias Accumulation Under Iteration¶

The Monte Carlo value iteration algorithm applies this empirical operator repeatedly:

vk+1≈L^Nvk.v_{k+1} \approx \widehat{\Bellman}_N v_k.vk+1​≈LN​vk​.
(61)

At every iteration, for every state, we:

  1. Generate noisy estimates of expected returns for each action.

  2. Take a maximum over these noisy estimates.

  3. Use this maximum as the new value estimate and feed it into the next iteration.

The upward bias therefore does not cancel out over time. Instead, it can be amplified in two ways.

First, the algorithm is recursive: the next round of Monte Carlo estimates is taken around a value function that is already slightly too optimistic. When we maximize over noisy estimates again, the new “bump” from favorable noise is added on top of the previous one.

Second, once a state–action pair has been overestimated through a lucky sequence of samples, it becomes more attractive in the maximization step. The algorithm will tend to pick it again, which increases the chance of reinforcing that overestimate. Negative noise, in contrast, tends to be ignored because it lowers an action’s estimated value and makes it less likely to be selected.

The result is an algorithm that, in expectation, computes a value function that satisfies

E[vk]≥v∗\mathbb{E}[v_k] \ge v^*E[vk​]≥v∗
(62)

componentwise, where v∗v^*v∗ is the true optimal value function. How large the gap becomes depends on the variance of the Monte Carlo estimates, the number of actions, and the number of iterations. But the important qualitative fact is that the gap is systematically upward.

Implications for Value Iteration¶

In the exact, model-based setting, value iteration has two reassuring properties:

  1. The Bellman operator is a contraction, so repeated application converges to v∗v^*v∗.

  2. The sequence of values remains “honest” in the sense that each iterate is the result of applying a deterministic operator to the previous iterate.

Once we replace L\BellmanL with L^N\widehat{\Bellman}_NLN​, both properties need to be revisited. Our operator is now random, and, because of the maximization over noisy estimates, it is optimistic on average. The algorithm tends to overstate the achievable return, even if the number of samples NNN is held fixed and the number of iterations goes to infinity.

This upward bias appears in many reinforcement learning algorithms that bootstrap and maximize over noisy value estimates, and it motivates a whole family of variance-reduction and “double” methods that we will encounter later in the chapter.

Learning the Bias Correction¶

We now turn to methods for addressing the overestimation bias introduced by maximizing over noisy Monte Carlo estimates. The approach we examine here, developed by Keane and Wolpin Keane & Wolpin (1994) in the context of dynamic discrete choice models, takes a direct approach: learn a model of the bias itself, then subtract it from the Bellman updates.

For a given value function vvv and Monte Carlo sample size NNN, define the bias at state sss as

δ(s)=E[(L^Nv)(s)]−(Lv)(s).\delta(s) = \mathbb{E}\big[(\widehat{\Bellman}_N v)(s)\big] - (\Bellman v)(s).δ(s)=E[(LN​v)(s)]−(Lv)(s).
(63)

If we could compute δ(s)\delta(s)δ(s), we could correct our empirical updates by subtracting it. While we cannot compute either the expectation E[(L^Nv)(s)]\mathbb{E}[(\widehat{\Bellman}_N v)(s)]E[(LN​v)(s)] or the exact Bellman application (Lv)(s)(\Bellman v)(s)(Lv)(s) directly, the bias δ(s)\delta(s)δ(s) depends on observable quantities:

  1. The number of Monte Carlo samples NNN: more samples reduce variance and thus reduce the bias from maximization.

  2. The number of actions ∣As∣|\mathcal{A}_s|∣As​∣: more actions increase the chance that at least one gets a favorable draw.

  3. The spread of action values: when actions have similar values, small noise can flip the maximizer.

Rather than computing δ(s)\delta(s)δ(s) analytically, Keane and Wolpin proposed learning it empirically. The strategy is to perform high-fidelity simulation at a subset of states to estimate the bias, then fit a regression model that predicts the bias from simple features. This learned correction can then be applied throughout the state space.

The method follows the “simulate on a subset, interpolate everywhere” template common in econometric dynamic programming. At a carefully chosen set of states, we simulate the Bellman operator with both high and low fidelity to estimate the bias. We then build a regression surrogate that predicts this bias from features of the state and action-value distribution. During routine value iteration, we use the fast low-fidelity Monte Carlo estimate and subtract the predicted bias correction.

To formalize this, consider a state sss with current value function vvv. Let

μ(s,a)=∫v(s′) p(ds′∣s,a),μ^N(s,a)=1N∑i=1Nv(si′)\mu(s,a) = \int v(s') \, p(ds' \mid s,a), \qquad \hat{\mu}_N(s,a) = \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N v(s'_i)μ(s,a)=∫v(s′)p(ds′∣s,a),μ^​N​(s,a)=N1​i=1∑N​v(si′​)
(64)

where si′∼p(⋅∣s,a)s'_i \sim p(\cdot \mid s,a)si′​∼p(⋅∣s,a). With Monte Carlo sampling, we compute max⁡aμ^N(s,a)\max_a \hat{\mu}_N(s,a)maxa​μ^​N​(s,a). The noise-free target for the maximization step is max⁡aμ(s,a)\max_a \mu(s,a)maxa​μ(s,a). The gap

δ(s)=E[max⁡aμ^N(s,a)]−max⁡aμ(s,a)≥0\delta(s) = \mathbb{E}\big[\max_a \hat{\mu}_N(s,a)\big] - \max_a \mu(s,a) \geq 0δ(s)=E[amax​μ^​N​(s,a)]−amax​μ(s,a)≥0
(65)

is what we aim to learn. Once we have an estimator δ^(s)\hat{\delta}(s)δ^(s), we can form a bias-corrected update:

r(s,a⋆)+γ(max⁡aμ^N(s,a)−δ^(s)).r(s,a^\star) + \gamma\Big(\max_a \hat{\mu}_N(s,a) - \hat{\delta}(s)\Big).r(s,a⋆)+γ(amax​μ^​N​(s,a)−δ^(s)).
(66)

The bias depends on the dispersion and cardinality of the action set. If one action dominates, δ(s)\delta(s)δ(s) is small. If several actions have similar values, δ(s)\delta(s)δ(s) grows because noise is more likely to change the maximizer. Useful features for predicting the bias include:

  • Gaps to the best action: ga(s)=max⁡a′μˉ(s,a′)−μˉ(s,a)g_a(s) = \max_{a'} \bar{\mu}(s,a') - \bar{\mu}(s,a)ga​(s)=maxa′​μˉ​(s,a′)−μˉ​(s,a), where μˉ\bar{\mu}μˉ​ is a low-variance estimate of action values (from a fitted value model or large-NNN simulation).

  • Aggregates of the gap distribution: min⁡aga\min_a g_amina​ga​ (zero by construction), mean(ga)\text{mean}(g_a)mean(ga​), std(ga)\text{std}(g_a)std(ga​), the top-2 gap.

  • Number of actions: log⁡∣As∣\log|\mathcal{A}_s|log∣As​∣.

  • Spread measures: log⁡∑aexp⁡(μˉ(s,a))−max⁡aμˉ(s,a)\log\sum_a \exp(\bar{\mu}(s,a)) - \max_a \bar{\mu}(s,a)log∑a​exp(μˉ​(s,a))−maxa​μˉ​(s,a), which captures how “soft” the maximum is.

These features are cheap to compute and track regimes where maximization bias is large.

The procedure has two phases. First, we perform a high-cost simulation pass at a subset of states to estimate the bias. Second, we fit a regression model to predict the bias from features.

  1. Choose a subset of states S⋆\mathcal{S}^\starS⋆ using a space-filling design over the state space.

  2. For each s∈S⋆s \in \mathcal{S}^\stars∈S⋆:

    • Compute a high-precision reference μref(s,a)\mu^{\text{ref}}(s,a)μref(s,a) using many draws (or exact integration in tractable models).

    • Form the deterministic max Mref(s)=max⁡aμref(s,a)M^{\text{ref}}(s) = \max_a \mu^{\text{ref}}(s,a)Mref(s)=maxa​μref(s,a).

    • Independently, compute a noisy max M^N(s)=max⁡aμ^N(s,a)\widehat{M}_N(s) = \max_a \hat{\mu}_N(s,a)MN​(s)=maxa​μ^​N​(s,a) using the same NNN that will be used in routine value iteration.

    • Record the gap y(s)=M^N(s)−Mref(s)y(s) = \widehat{M}_N(s) - M^{\text{ref}}(s)y(s)=MN​(s)−Mref(s).

    • Construct the feature vector ϕ(s)\phi(s)ϕ(s) from the gaps and spreads of μref(s,⋅)\mu^{\text{ref}}(s,\cdot)μref(s,⋅).

  3. Fit a regression model y≈gη(ϕ)y \approx g_\eta(\phi)y≈gη​(ϕ) using least squares or another fitting method.

  4. Freeze the fitted model gη^g_{\hat{\eta}}gη^​​. During routine value iteration, replace the raw noisy max with the bias-corrected expression that subtracts gη^(ϕ(s))g_{\hat{\eta}}(\phi(s))gη^​​(ϕ(s)).

The algorithm can be summarized as:

Algorithm 2 (Keane-Wolpin Bias-Corrected Update)

Input: MDP, current value model vvv, sample size NNN, learned correction gηg_\etagη​

Output: Bias-corrected value estimate at state sss

  1. For each action a∈Asa \in \mathcal{A}_sa∈As​:

    • Draw NNN next states s1′,…,sN′∼p(⋅∣s,a)s'_1, \ldots, s'_N \sim p(\cdot \mid s,a)s1′​,…,sN′​∼p(⋅∣s,a)

    • Compute μ^N(s,a)=1N∑i=1Nv(si′)\hat{\mu}_N(s,a) = \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N v(s'_i)μ^​N​(s,a)=N1​∑i=1N​v(si′​)

  2. Compute raw max: M^(s)=max⁡aμ^N(s,a)\widehat{M}(s) = \max_a \hat{\mu}_N(s,a)M(s)=maxa​μ^​N​(s,a)

  3. Construct features ϕ(s)\phi(s)ϕ(s) from a low-variance estimate of action values (from a separate large-NNN simulation)

  4. Return bias-corrected target: T(s)=r(s,a⋆)+γ[M^(s)−gη(ϕ(s))]T(s) = r(s,a^\star) + \gamma\big[\widehat{M}(s) - g_\eta(\phi(s))\big]T(s)=r(s,a⋆)+γ[M(s)−gη​(ϕ(s))]

Note that step 3 should use a separate, lower-variance estimate of action values to construct features, not the same noisy samples from step 1. This can be obtained from a separate high-fidelity simulation or by caching values from the training phase. This avoids using the same randomness twice and stabilizes the feature computation.

The Keane-Wolpin method has been influential in econometrics for estimating dynamic discrete choice models, where the goal is often structural parameter estimation rather than optimal control. However, it has seen limited adoption in reinforcement learning. The method’s computational overhead—requiring variance computation, high-fidelity simulation at training states, and careful feature engineering—makes it expensive relative to the alternatives we discuss next. More fundamentally, the circular dependency between the bias estimate and the value function can amplify errors: if the regression model gηg_\etagη​ is misspecified or estimated poorly, the correction can introduce more harm than the original bias. While the approach remains conceptually appealing as a principled way to learn and subtract systematic errors, it represents a research direction that has not been extensively developed in the reinforcement learning literature. We now turn to a simpler and more widely adopted approach: decoupling the selection and evaluation steps to reduce overestimation bias without explicit bias modeling.

Decoupling Selection and Evaluation¶

The Keane-Wolpin approach treated maximization bias as a quantity to be learned and subtracted. There is an alternative strategy that modifies the estimator itself so that the maximization step does not introduce systematic overestimation. The bias arises when we use the same noisy estimate both to select an action and to evaluate it. If we maintain two independent value estimates and use one to choose the action while the other evaluates it, we can eliminate the coupling that produces upward drift.

Consider the Monte Carlo Bellman operator L^N\widehat{\Bellman}_NLN​ applied at state sss. For each action aaa, we compute

q^N(s,a)=r(s,a)+γN∑i=1Nv(si′),\hat{q}_N(s,a) = r(s,a) + \frac{\gamma}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N v(s'_i),q^​N​(s,a)=r(s,a)+Nγ​i=1∑N​v(si′​),
(67)

where si′∼p(⋅∣s,a)s'_i \sim p(\cdot \mid s,a)si′​∼p(⋅∣s,a). The standard Monte Carlo update forms the target max⁡aq^N(s,a)\max_a \hat{q}_N(s,a)maxa​q^​N​(s,a). This maximum both selects the best action according to the noisy estimates and uses that same noise to compute the value. Write q^N(s,a)=q(s,a)+εa\hat{q}_N(s,a) = q(s,a) + \varepsilon_aq^​N​(s,a)=q(s,a)+εa​ where E[εa]=0\mathbb{E}[\varepsilon_a] = 0E[εa​]=0. Then

E[max⁡aq^N(s,a)]=E[max⁡a(q(s,a)+εa)]≥max⁡aq(s,a),\mathbb{E}\Big[\max_a \hat{q}_N(s,a)\Big] = \mathbb{E}\Big[\max_a (q(s,a) + \varepsilon_a)\Big] \geq \max_a q(s,a),E[amax​q^​N​(s,a)]=E[amax​(q(s,a)+εa​)]≥amax​q(s,a),
(68)

because the maximum of noisy variables exceeds the maximum of their means on average.

Suppose instead we maintain two independent Q-function approximations, q(1)(s,a)q^{(1)}(s,a)q(1)(s,a) and q(2)(s,a)q^{(2)}(s,a)q(2)(s,a), each with its own Monte Carlo noise. When updating q(1)q^{(1)}q(1), we use q(1)q^{(1)}q(1) to select the action but q(2)q^{(2)}q(2) to evaluate it:

Y(1)=r(s,a)+γ q(2)(s′,a⋆),where a⋆=arg⁡max⁡a′q(1)(s′,a′).Y^{(1)} = r(s,a) + \gamma \, q^{(2)}(s', a^\star), \quad \text{where } a^\star = \arg\max_{a'} q^{(1)}(s',a').Y(1)=r(s,a)+γq(2)(s′,a⋆),where a⋆=arga′max​q(1)(s′,a′).
(69)

Symmetrically, when updating q(2)q^{(2)}q(2), we reverse the roles:

Y(2)=r(s,a)+γ q(1)(s′,a⋆),where a⋆=arg⁡max⁡a′q(2)(s′,a′).Y^{(2)} = r(s,a) + \gamma \, q^{(1)}(s', a^\star), \quad \text{where } a^\star = \arg\max_{a'} q^{(2)}(s',a').Y(2)=r(s,a)+γq(1)(s′,a⋆),where a⋆=arga′max​q(2)(s′,a′).
(70)

To see why this reduces bias, consider the first update. The action a⋆a^\stara⋆ is selected based on the noise in q(1)q^{(1)}q(1). The evaluation q(2)(s′,a⋆)q^{(2)}(s', a^\star)q(2)(s′,a⋆) uses the noise in q(2)q^{(2)}q(2). If these two sources of noise are independent, then conditional on the selected action a⋆a^\stara⋆,

E[q(2)(s′,a⋆)∣a⋆]=q⋆(s′,a⋆),\mathbb{E}\big[q^{(2)}(s', a^\star) \mid a^\star\big] = q^\star(s', a^\star),E[q(2)(s′,a⋆)∣a⋆]=q⋆(s′,a⋆),
(71)

where q⋆q^\starq⋆ denotes the true Q-value. Taking expectations over a⋆a^\stara⋆, the estimator remains unbiased. There is no extra positive term from the maximum of noise, because the maximization step never sees the noise used in the evaluation. The coupling is broken.

This is the principle behind double Q-learning Van Hasselt et al. (2016). We maintain two Q-functions q(1)q^{(1)}q(1) and q(2)q^{(2)}q(2) and alternate which one selects actions and which one evaluates them during value iteration. The following algorithm implements this with Monte Carlo integration. The maximization bias is a property of taking the max over noisy estimates, independent of whether we use a table, linear approximation, or neural networks to represent the Q-functions.

Algorithm 3 (Double Q Value Iteration with Monte Carlo)

Input: MDP, state sample S\mathcal{S}S, Monte Carlo sample size NNN, maximum iterations KKK

Output: Two Q-functions q(1)q^{(1)}q(1), q(2)q^{(2)}q(2)

  1. Initialize q0(1)(s,a)q^{(1)}_0(s,a)q0(1)​(s,a) and q0(2)(s,a)q^{(2)}_0(s,a)q0(2)​(s,a) for all s,as,as,a

  2. k←0k \leftarrow 0k←0

  3. repeat

  4. \quad for each s∈Ss \in \mathcal{S}s∈S do

  5. \quad\quad for each a∈A(s)a \in \mathcal{A}(s)a∈A(s) do

  6. \quad\quad\quad Draw NNN next states: s1′,…,sN′∼p(⋅∣s,a)s'_1, \ldots, s'_N \sim p(\cdot \mid s,a)s1′​,…,sN′​∼p(⋅∣s,a)

  7. \quad\quad\quad // Compute targets using decoupled selection-evaluation

  8. \quad\quad\quad for i=1,…,Ni = 1, \ldots, Ni=1,…,N do

  9. \quad\quad\quad\quad ai(1)←arg⁡max⁡a′qk(1)(si′,a′)a^{(1)}_i \leftarrow \arg\max_{a'} q^{(1)}_k(s'_i, a')ai(1)​←argmaxa′​qk(1)​(si′​,a′)

  10. \quad\quad\quad\quad ai(2)←arg⁡max⁡a′qk(2)(si′,a′)a^{(2)}_i \leftarrow \arg\max_{a'} q^{(2)}_k(s'_i, a')ai(2)​←argmaxa′​qk(2)​(si′​,a′)

  11. \quad\quad\quad end for

  12. \quad\quad\quad qk+1(1)(s,a)←r(s,a)+γN∑i=1Nqk(2)(si′,ai(1))q^{(1)}_{k+1}(s,a) \leftarrow r(s,a) + \frac{\gamma}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N q^{(2)}_k(s'_i, a^{(1)}_i)qk+1(1)​(s,a)←r(s,a)+Nγ​∑i=1N​qk(2)​(si′​,ai(1)​)

  13. \quad\quad\quad qk+1(2)(s,a)←r(s,a)+γN∑i=1Nqk(1)(si′,ai(2))q^{(2)}_{k+1}(s,a) \leftarrow r(s,a) + \frac{\gamma}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N q^{(1)}_k(s'_i, a^{(2)}_i)qk+1(2)​(s,a)←r(s,a)+Nγ​∑i=1N​qk(1)​(si′​,ai(2)​)

  14. \quad\quad end for

  15. \quad end for

  16. \quad k←k+1k \leftarrow k+1k←k+1

  17. until convergence or k≥Kk \geq Kk≥K

  18. return qk(1)q^{(1)}_kqk(1)​, qk(2)q^{(2)}_kqk(2)​

At lines 9-10, we use q(1)q^{(1)}q(1) to select the action for updating q(1)q^{(1)}q(1), but then at line 12 we evaluate that action using q(2)q^{(2)}q(2). This decouples the noise in the selection step from the noise in the evaluation step. The same principle applies symmetrically for q(2)q^{(2)}q(2) at lines 10 and 13. The Monte Carlo averages are unbiased for the expected values of the selected actions, and the maximization bias is removed because selection and evaluation use independent noise sources. This principle applies whether we store Q-values in a table or use function approximation.

  2. Van Hasselt, H., Guez, A., & Silver, D. (2016). Deep Reinforcement Learning with Double Q-learning. Proceedings of the AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence, 30(1).
